<h4>At a glance</h4>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Fbusiness%20functions%2Fsustainability%2Four%20insights%2Ften%20key%20requirements%20for%20a%20systemic%20approach%20to%20climate%20adaptation%2Ften-key-requirements-for-a-systemic-approach-to-climate-adaptation.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="ten-key-requirements-for-a-systemic-approach-to-climate-adaptation" data-layer-report-name="ten-key-requirements-for-a-systemic-approach-to-climate-adaptation>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (21 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<ul>
    <li>Humanity has already experienced climate change in the course of its long evolution and responded through various forms of adaptation. However, todayâs climate challenge differs in two important ways from those of the past. First, it is happening much more quickly than ever before. Second, climate risks are rising in the context of established and complex systems, including where and how crops are grown, cities built, goods and services produced, supply chains organized, and other economic activities conducted. Such systems have been built on the assumption of a stable climate and, in the absence of an appropriate response, are clearly at risk from climate change.</li>
    <li>These differences have three critical implications. The first is that adaptation will be necessary but not sufficient on its own to manage a changing climate effectively over time. Second, any forward-looking approach to adaptation must be substantially more deliberate than the organic approaches of the past were. The last is that as with the transition to a net-zero economy, adaptation requires a systemic view to support local, national, and global efforts and to ensure that it is as orderly and effective as possible.</li>
    <li>The research behind this article develops a framework for a systemic response to adaptation, highlighting all the elements that must come together in a linked and connected way. We identify ten key requirements across four categories: a climate risk management mindset; technological and behavioral adaptation levers; economic and societal adjustments; and governance, institutional support, and commitment.</li>
    <li>For each of these ten requirements, we found early examples of progress. For example, many of the technological and behavioral solutions needed for successful adaptation already exist in some formâin contrast to mitigation, where the required technologies are still lacking in certain sectors. Likewise, climate data has become much more accessible in both public and private forms, and hazard and economic-loss models are maturing. However, across the board, progress remains nascent. For instance, while some initial progress has been made in the public sectorâ84 percent of 197 individual sovereign states plus the European Union have published some version of a national adaptation planâlarge gaps remain.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b9eaa713-1a48-4579-88f1-f3a64a1e139f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b9eaa713-1a48-4579-88f1-f3a64a1e139f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Adaptation gap report 2022: Too little, too slow</em>, United Nations Environment Program.</span></span></span></a></span> The majority of these plans lack a sense of risk preference or tolerance (that is, how much risk can be accepted). Adaptation solutions typically are not fully tied back to the physical risks they ameliorate, and the required investment levels are often not specified. Most important, the majority of these plans must still be resourced and executed.</li>
    <li>As private- and public-sector actors consider the framework proposed in this article, it is important to note that not all parts of the world will be equally exposed to rising risks during this decade. Even the exposed parts of the world may not face equally severe risks. These differences are not a justification for inaction. On the contrary, it is important for all parties to use this time as an opportunity to deploy the adaptation measures needed in the near term, to embed adaptation considerations in decisions that have long-lived consequences, and to build the capabilities needed to make robust adaptation decisions over the longer term. This will take both time and effort.</li>
    <li>In adaptation as in mitigation, it is crucial not to let the perfect be the enemy of the good. Numerous measures can be embarked on today with relative easeâfor example, beginning to develop a climate risk management mindset to evaluate and implement adaptation decisions and deploying technological and behavioral solutions (such as the greening of urban spaces or painting roofs white to manage heat) that are relatively low cost, have co-benefits, and do not pose maladaptation risks.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p><strong>From the dawn of <em>Homo sapiens</em>,</strong> around 200,000 years ago, to the present day, adaptation has been humanityâs primary response to changes in the Earthâs climate. In other terms, as the climate has changed, humanity has  gradually altered its way of life to thrive under new conditions. Indeed, the spread of early humans out of Africa and across the globe was inspired by the search for favorable environmental conditions during a geological period of great climate disruption. Over the last several hundred thousand years, the Earthâs climateâdriven by orbital changesâhas cycled between temperate periods and glacial ones, when much of the Northern Hemisphere was covered in ice. The spread of <em>Homo sapiens</em> across the world corresponds strongly to the resulting patterns of shifting temperature, rainfall, and vegetation.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f50b2502-0b59-4b92-a904-c6ef3657717b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f50b2502-0b59-4b92-a904-c6ef3657717b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">A. Timmerman et al., âClimate effects on archaic human habitats and species successions,â <em>Nature</em>, April 13, 2022, Volume 604.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Such organic adaptation efforts continue to take place in the context of todayâs climate exposures, though with the benefit of tens of thousands of years of societal and technological progress. For example, to manage heat risk, GIFT City, a central business district under construction in the state of Gujarat in India, is building a district cooling system that distributes centrally chilled water to consumers through underground pipes. Compared with fitting out protected homes with individual air-conditioning units, this system reduces the energy demand of providing cooling assistance by 35 to 50 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ef4bc147-107d-4a96-a4f2-02240d82758a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ef4bc147-107d-4a96-a4f2-02240d82758a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>International Monetary Fund: Climate change and environment</em>, âAdapting to climate changeâthree success stories,â blog entry by Mico Mrkaic and Evgenia Pugacheva, March 20, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> The Netherlands, which faces severe flood risk because of its low elevation, is widening rivers, digging flood channels, and adding catchment areas. As a result, the major rivers that make up the Netherlands delta can now safely carry thousands more cubic meters of water per second than they could 30 years ago.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9f1e78f6-280d-4abd-ae28-729e139e5be2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9f1e78f6-280d-4abd-ae28-729e139e5be2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">âRoom for the River Program,â Integrated Water Management Case, April 15, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>However, todayâs climate change challenge differs in five important ways from the earlier instances in the course of human evolution:</p>
<ol>
    <li>Climate change is now the direct result of human activity and bound to continue until net-zero emissions are reached. In past cases, humanity was merely a âtakerâ of change; it is now also its maker. Humanity therefore faces a dual task: mitigating climate change (and, more broadly, regaining an equilibrium with nature) <em>and</em> adapting to the impact of the change that has already occurred or is âbanked.â Another facet of anthropogenic climate change is that it is more uncertain, both given uncertainty about how human activity could shift and uncertainty related to the modeling of the impact of climate change. Decision-makers must therefore act in a context of uncertainty about the magnitude of the changes ahead, as they depend on the decisions of others.</li>
    <li>It is happening much more quickly than it did in the previous instances of greenhouse gasâdriven climate change. Indeed, the rate of present-day carbon release has no precedent during the last 66 million years, at least.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6dba4d2c-0f12-4944-8dcc-a3137d81ed7f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6dba4d2c-0f12-4944-8dcc-a3137d81ed7f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">R. Zeebe et al., âAnthropogenic carbon release rate unprecedented during the past 66 million years,â <em>Nature Geoscience</em>, March 2016, Volume 9, pp. 325â29.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li>With temperatures already higher than at any time in the past 125,000 years,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="82c03613-629a-428a-b5d4-a1d466f5211b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="82c03613-629a-428a-b5d4-a1d466f5211b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">V. Masson-Delmotte, P. Zhai, et al. (editors), <em>Climate Change 2021: The Physical Science Basis</em>, Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, Cambridge and New York: Cambridge University Press, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> additional warming threatens to create, for the first time in human history, temperatures beyond the general tolerance of multiple species, from human beings to warm-water coralsâfundamentally threatening the habitability of some of the most populated parts of the Earth.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8c799725-43d9-473f-b22b-65e887ed3215"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8c799725-43d9-473f-b22b-65e887ed3215" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">C. Raymond et al., âThe emergence of heat and humidity too severe for human tolerance,â <em>Science Advances</em>, May 8, 2020, Volume 6, Issue 19.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li>Natural capital is being depleted across multiple planetary boundariesâfor example, the biosphereâs integrity, biogeochemical flows, and ozone depletionâand faster than it can be rebuilt. This both magnifies<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="95ef55a5-b550-4617-bc9b-cefa7d76fc9c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="95ef55a5-b550-4617-bc9b-cefa7d76fc9c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">J. Rockstrom et al., âA safe operating space for humanity,â <em>Nature</em>, September 2009, Volume 461, pp. 472â75.</span></span></span></a></span> the impacts of a changing climate and is magnified by it.</li>
    <li>Climate change is now happening in the context of a much larger human population and a civilization that has evolved in a period of climate stability and is predicated, in fundamental ways, on the assumption that this stability will continue. Human well-being depends at present on a highly complex economy built around geographically fixed physical assets, sedentary populations, and political boundaries that make some of the past solutions, such as at-scale migration, much harder. All these systems have not only been built for a different climate but are also, in many cases, already functioning on the edge of their capacity because of age, population growth, or other nonclimate factors.</li>
</ol>
<p>These five differences have three critical implications.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>First, adaptation will be necessary but not sufficient on its own to manage a changing climate over time effectively. Indeed, even in a hypothetical idealized scenario in which emissions stopped today, the impact of climate change would continue to intensify as parts of our planet slowly adjusted to this new, warmer, climate state.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5e7f72a2-f36d-4d83-ac02-90d1e86a7933"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5e7f72a2-f36d-4d83-ac02-90d1e86a7933" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">V. Masson-Delmotte, P. Zhai, et al. (editors), <em>Climate Change 2021: The Physical Science Basis</em>, Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, Cambridge and New York: Cambridge University Press, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> This would hold true even if one were to achieve the goals enshrined in the 2015 Paris Agreement, which aims to limit warming to well below 2Â°C (and ideally 1.5Â°C) relative to preindustrial levels.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f14a5a22-77c5-4547-9ae3-6fd4d6763523"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f14a5a22-77c5-4547-9ae3-6fd4d6763523" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Throughout this article, we refer to warming levels (e.g., 1.5Â°C, 2.0Â°C, 2.5Â°C). All references as such are to a global mean temperature increase above preindustrial levels.</span></span></span></a></span> However, recent studies from the United Nations have found that global emission trends are already offtrack from the mitigation pathways needed to meet the Paris Agreementâs temperature goals and that the window to change course is rapidly closing.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b21bf776-6c58-4e78-8e7f-0482b3d824ea"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b21bf776-6c58-4e78-8e7f-0482b3d824ea" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Technical dialogue of the first global stocktake</em>, United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, September 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The limits to adaptation</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>Adaptation must</strong> go hand in hand with mitigation because until net-zero emissions are achieved, the temperature of our planet, and therefore physical risk, will continue to increase. This requirement must be coupled with an awareness of the hard and soft limits on the level of risk that adaptation can alleviate.</p>
<p>Hard limits mean that a climate impact has no feasible adaptation levers. Some commonly cited examples are the threat to small island nations from rising sea levels or the loss of the climate conditions necessary for specific ecosystems. For instance, it has been estimated that if global warming exceeds 2Â°C, more than 20 percent of living species might be endangered by the loss of viable climate conditions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0767417a-2ca0-453d-8f18-63c5edbe1860"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0767417a-2ca0-453d-8f18-63c5edbe1860" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">C<em>limate Change 2022: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability: Summary for Policymakers</em>.</span></span></span></a></span> Another example is the permanent depletion of freshwater resources for communities that depend on glacier melt for river flow: in Nepal over the past decade, for instance, the flows of 70 percent of glacier-fed rivers have decreased, and 12 percent have disappeared entirely.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="040032c4-f386-4030-911a-4a16f1ee013f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="040032c4-f386-4030-911a-4a16f1ee013f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">C<em>limate Change 2022: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability: Summary for Policymakers</em>.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Soft limits are financial, technological, or institutional barriers that prevent successful adaptation. For example, if global warming were to reach 3Â°C, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) estimates that it would be cost-prohibitive to adapt all human settlements currently at risk for one-in-100-year floods to the ensuing increase in flood risk.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a40a0728-9cd9-4be6-8317-c2a130aed286"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a40a0728-9cd9-4be6-8317-c2a130aed286" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">C<em>limate Change 2022: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability: Summary for Policymakers</em>.</span></span></span></a></span> Another example is the emergence across South Asia of humid-heat levels too extreme for human beings to work outdoors during the day. Technological solutionsâfor example, mechanizing or air-conditioning all agricultural, construction, and transport workâcould be available. Yet financial, governance, institutional, and policy constraints might make these solutions immensely challenging to deploy.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="139a95b8-85b4-42ab-ba06-25d3f5bb95b7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="139a95b8-85b4-42ab-ba06-25d3f5bb95b7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">C<em>limate Change 2022: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability: Summary for Policymakers</em>.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Recent research from the IPCC suggests that, particularly for natural systems, the Earth is already nearing its soft or hard adaptation limits and that society will begin to cross some of them when global warming consistently rises more than 1.5Â°C above preindustrial levels. (This is considered the threshold for preventing the most dangerous and irreversible effects of climate change.) Of course, in both natural and other systems, these limits will not manifest themselves equally across the world.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c234c50d-fffa-4057-8299-9eb647caee96"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c234c50d-fffa-4057-8299-9eb647caee96" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">B. O'Neill et al., âKey Risks Across Sectors and Regions,â in <em>Climate Change 2022: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability</em>.</span></span></span></a></span> Nor are the warming levels and the timing of such manifestations certain. There may, as a result, be more opportunity to rely on adaptation in a number of cases.</p>
<p>These hard and soft limits do not negate the importance of rapidly ramping up adaptation efforts. They do, however, raise several questions. The first is how to best allocate resources between mitigation and adaptation. Second, how can adaptation levers minimize conflict between the hard and soft limits? For example, improving the deployment of air-conditioning is a necessary adaptation to the most severe heat impacts of climate change, but this lever will probably increase emissions through both higher electricity demand and coolant leakage. Third, how can adaptation expenditures most efficaciously be targeted toward risks that countries can address without hitting the near-term limitsâfor example, by retreating from areas that will clearly become uneconomical to defend in the future.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>At the same time,  there are both hard (physical) and soft (institutional or economic) limits to what adaptation alone can achieve. Recent research suggests that the world may already be approaching at least some (though by no means all) of these limits (see sidebar âThe limits to adaptationâ). As such, adaptation and mitigation must occur together: this is a true case of âand,â not âor.â In fact, there is a nexus between climate adaptation, climate mitigation, natural capital restoration, and economic development, which could have clear co-benefits in some areas if pursued together judiciously.</p>
<p>The second implication is that todayâs approach to adaptation must be substantially more deliberate than the organic approaches of the past were. Because nearly every aspect of our societyâfrom where houses are built and crops grown to how engineering and design standards are set to how capital is investedâis predicated on the implicit assumption of climate stability, significant adaptation will be necessary over time to prevent major disruption to current socioeconomic systems, particularly at higher levels of warming. Adaptation will require a fundamental shift in assumptions about risk. There will be a need not only to use physical levers, such as building seawalls and installing air-conditioning units, but also to change behavior and rethink approaches to the transfer of risk.</p>
<p>In addition, present-day climate change is occurring at a time when other important risksâmacroeconomic, geopolitical, and public-health relatedâalso threaten the stability of the worldâs economic and social systems, as well as the lives and livelihoods of those who depend on them. These risks can act as multipliers for one another and hasten highly challenging outcomes.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bdbfa425-413d-440b-926a-0a4b12862e9c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bdbfa425-413d-440b-926a-0a4b12862e9c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">T. Homer-Dixon et al., <em>A call for an international research program on the risk of a global polycrisis</em>, Cascade Institute, July 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In short, organic adaption is no longer sufficient. At the same time, however, this situation presents a real opportunity. By carefully embedding climate risk considerations in the natural cycle of upgrades to existing systems or the creation of new ones, the world can adapt to rising risks in a more deliberate way and, likely, at a lower total cost.</p>
<p>The third implication is that, as with the transition to a net-zero economy, adaptation requires a systemic view to support local, national, and global efforts. That systemic view is the focus of this report. The question we are aiming to answer is what is an end-to-end framework for all the elements that must come together to enable the type of systemic change that adaptation requires. The report does not contend that all concerned would need to focus equally and at all times on all the elements of such a framework, but rather that the framework would allow the private, public, and social sectors to ensure that they are designing and implementing comprehensive (and therefore effective) adaptation strategies while diagnosing the challenges hindering progress and determining where collaboration is needed.</p>
<p>We undertook a similar exercise for the net-zero transition in a 2021 article, â<a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/solving-the-net-zero-equation-nine-requirements-for-a-more-orderly-transition">Solving the net-zero equation: Nine requirements for a more orderly transition</a>,â which highlighted nine requirements divided among three broad categories: physical building blocks; economic and societal adjustments; and governance, institutions, and commitments. Our aim was both to describe all the elements needed to mitigate climate change and to emphasize that they must come together in a connected way. Indeed, just as the impact of climate change is systemic, so too must be the approach to the net-zero transition. There are links among funding needs, technological innovation, standards and institutions, and mechanisms to address the transitionâs regressive effects, to name a few, and their mutual influences and impacts need to be well-understood to enable effective action.</p>

data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Summary of the ten requirements</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>This report identifies</strong> ten key requirements across four categories: a climate-risk-management mindset; technological and behavioral adaptation levers; economic and societal adjustments; and governance, institutional support, and commitment.</p>
<h3>A climate-risk-management mindset</h3>
<p><em>1. A granular understanding of evolving physical risk and its implications under different future climate scenarios.</em> Such an understanding should be built around both a central, likely scenario (which would then be the basis for adaptation planning) and a number of alternate ones. Data is becoming more readily available, but investments in accessibility and education would be needed to ensure greater effectiveness.</p>
<p><em>2. A deep understanding of risk preferences and adaptation trade-offs.</em> Such an understanding requires clarity about the degree and time horizons of warming (and hence hazards) that a nation, region, or company is preparing for; which risks it must adapt to as a result; and the degree to which they can be reduced. These questions can be answered only when an entity has a dynamic understanding of its risk tolerance and means.</p>
<h3>Technological and behavioral adaptation levers</h3>
<p><em>3. The availability of technological and physical interventions to adapt to physical risks.</em> Many of the technologies and physical measures needed for adaptation to present and future climate risks already exist. But over time, adaptation at scale would require further driving down costs, addressing deployment hurdles, capturing co-benefits, and managing maladaptation risks.</p>
<p><em>4. Acceptance of behavioral interventions for adapting to physical risks.</em> Behavioral solutions encompass a broad suite of actions, ranging from changing operational practices and preferences to reducing the exposure of assets. Many of these have already been used to manage existing environmental risks, but they now need to manage a changing climate. As climate change progresses, the solutions could become more disruptive, requiring adjustments to societal expectations and compensating mechanisms for the regressive effects of climate change.</p>
<h3>Economic and societal adjustments</h3>
<p><em>5. Effective capital allocation and financing structures.</em> Ensuring sufficient capital to meet adaptation needs would require both increasingly accurate estimates of costs (by combining the capabilities described above) and financial innovation to direct private capital into traditionally publicly funded activities. Such innovations could include expanding publicâprivate financing, better use of standards and incentives to promote action, and the creation of new financial instruments and markets, such as adaptation credits.</p>
<p><em>6. Effective risk pricing and transfer mechanisms.</em> By creating transparency about the magnitude of risks and helping individuals more effectively bear them, effective risk pricing can help adaptation decision making and deployment. Ensuring sufficient risk pricing and transfer would require improving the quality and disclosure of climate risk information, adapting insurance systems through such means as blended publicâprivate mechanisms, and potentially establishing linkages between the provision of insurance and a willingness to undertake specific adaptation actions.</p>
<p><em>7. Compensating mechanisms for vulnerable states, communities, and institutions.</em> The least economically developed parts of the world are often those most at risk from a changing climate. Ensuring a robust flow of capital to these regions in a way that does not increase their vulnerability (for instance, by increasing indebtedness) would therefore be essential for effective adaptation.</p>
<h3>Governance, institutional support, and commitment</h3>
<p><em>8. Effective governing institutions and policies.</em> Both effective governance and clear policies will be needed to promote successful adaptation. Global organizations, regulators, and governments can assume the role of defining and enforcing action. Without such interventions, misaligned incentives could make it impossible in the near term to take the steps needed for the right level of adaptation.</p>
<p><em>9. Community awareness and engagement.</em> Adaptation, at its core, is hyperlocal. Effective measures would involve communities and citizens in both planning and execution to help generate buy-in from those affected and to ensure that adaptation decisions reflect local priorities.</p>
<p><em>10. Commitment by and among public and private leaders both locally and globally.</em> Cooperation across public- and private-sector actors will be critical for successful adaptation. Commitments by both would need to be paired with geographic coordination and coordination over time to ensure that resources are deployed equitably and effectively.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>This report aims to do the same for adaptation. The difference in context is that the thinking about adaptation is much more nascent, so the gaps are even more pronounced. In that spirit, we propose a framework of ten fundamental requirements for fostering local and global adaptation efforts in the most effective and orderly way possible (see sidebar âSummary of the ten requirementsâ).</p>
<p>As private- and public-sector actors consider this framework, it is important for them to note that not all parts of the world will be equally exposed to rising risks during this decade. Even parts of the world that are exposed may not face equally severe risks. Nonetheless, it is important for all countries and regions to use this time as an opportunity to deploy the necessary near-term adaptation measures, to embed adaptation considerations into near-term decisions that have long-lived consequences (for example, designing enduring infrastructure assets that can also withstand future risks), and, finally, to build the capabilities to make the appropriate adaptation decisions over the longer term.</p>
<h2>The progress to date</h2>
<p>Some initial progress has been made on more deliberate adaptation. In the public sector, at least 84 percent of the 198 parties (197 sovereign states plus the European Union) to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCC) have established at least some adaptation plans, strategies, laws, and policies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cf69e3a3-edd2-4229-82a3-548591105d5d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cf69e3a3-edd2-4229-82a3-548591105d5d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Adaptation gap report 2022: Too little, too slow</em>, United Nations Environment Program.</span></span></span></a></span> Further, even some countries with no national plan, such as India and the United States, have state-specific plans in some instances.</p>
<p>Yet most of the existing adaptation plans do not account for the level of risk they deem acceptable, the warming level to which they plan to adapt, the specific risks they expect at that level of warming, the adaptation levers they will apply to manage those risks, the limits to what proposed adaptation levers can achieve, and the total cost of adaptation. Only the most advanced players across sectors and geographies have started thinking about this. Beyond the need for planning, the 2022 United Nations Environment Program (UNEP) <em>Adaptation Gap Report</em> emphasizes that incorporating risk thinking into strategy, providing the necessary financing, and acting to adapt to the new realities of climate are also all lagging behind what is needed.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b040ec1e-ba80-4883-b3ef-b65669406933"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b040ec1e-ba80-4883-b3ef-b65669406933" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Adaptation gap report 2022: Too little, too slow</em>, United Nations Environment Program.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>A framework for scaling global adaptation efforts</h2>
<p>At the highest level, we see four<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b09eb124-6c02-426b-aae7-1099f68d89a9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b09eb124-6c02-426b-aae7-1099f68d89a9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">This report presents a holistic framework describing the requirements needed for scaling global adaptation efforts to first- and second-order climate risks: those posed directly to specific assets by identifiable physical hazards or to stakeholders through the disruption of specific asset services (for instance, the damage to an electric power plant resulting from a storm versus the resulting impact for electricity customers). Individual stakeholders can adapt to first- and second-order risks. We leave third-order, or systemic, risk (such as the risk posed to the stability of the broader electric grid and all of the systems that depend on its functioning) as a topic for future work, since it is necessary to adapt to third-order risk at a societal level.</span></span></span></a></span> main categories of adaptation requirements:</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>A climate risk management mindset:</em> building a deep understanding of existing risks and how they are expected to evolve, as well as setting explicit risk preferences and tolerancesâall aided by the data and information systems needed to support decision-making.</li>
    <li><em>Technological and behavioral adaptation levers:</em> having the solutions, both technological and behavioral, to fulfill current and future adaptation requirements and ensuring that these solutions are widely accessibleâin other words, developing the supply chains and securing the resources that would facilitate their deployment.</li>
    <li><em>Economic and societal adjustments:</em> having the financing needed to deploy adaptation solutions; the effective recognition, distribution, and pricing of risk; and support for the communities most vulnerable to it.</li>
    <li><em>Governance, institutional support, and commitment:</em> having the institutions, policies, awareness, and community and leadership support needed to promote adaptation.</li>
</ol>
<p>Specifically, the report identifies ten key requirements across the four categories (Exhibit 1). What falls under each of these requirements is not static and must constantly be reexamined and addressed in light of both evolving risks and progress made.</p>
